title: Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa, Actor in â€˜Mortal Kombatâ€™ and â€˜The Man in the High Castle,â€™ Dies at 75
description: Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa, who played evil sorcerer Shang Tsung in the â€œMortal Kombatâ€ franchise and appeared in â€œThe Last Emperor,â€ â€œLicence to Killâ€ an
body:
Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa, who played evil sorcerer Shang Tsung in the â€œMortal Kombatâ€ franchise and appeared in â€œThe Last Emperor,â€ â€œLicence to Killâ€ and â€œThe Man in the High Castle,â€ died Thursday in Santa Barbara. A rep confirmed he died of complications from a stroke. He was 75.

	Tagawaâ€™s first film role came in Bernardo Bertolucciâ€™s â€œThe Last Emperor.â€ Soon after that, Tagawa played the villian Kwang in James Bond movie â€œLicence to Kill.â€
	

	On TV, he had a recurring role on â€œNash Bridgesâ€ and guest spots on dozens of series including â€œMiami Vice,â€ â€œKnots Landing,â€ â€œMoonlightingâ€ and â€œBaywatch.â€


	Kagawa is known for his role as Shang Tsung in the â€œMortal Kombatâ€ franchise. He appeared in the first film adaptation in 1995 and went on to appear in the TV series â€œMortal Kombat: Legacyâ€ in 2013 and lent his voice to the more recent â€œMortal Kombat 11â€ videogame.

	His other film roles include â€œRising Sun,â€ â€œSnow Falling on Cedars,â€ â€œPearl Harbor,â€ â€œPlanet of the Apesâ€ and â€œMemoirs of a Geisha.â€

	In Amazonâ€™s TV series â€œThe Man in the High Castle,â€ Tagawa starred as Trade Minister Nobusuke Tagomi; in Netflixâ€™s â€œLost in Space,â€ he played Hiroki Watanabe.

	Though he often played villains, Tagawa told the Honolulu Advertiser in 2007 that the type-casting was inevitable at the time. â€œGuaranteed, I wouldnâ€™t have gotten to play good guys if I hadnâ€™t played those bad guys,â€ Tagawa said.

	â€œItâ€™s something you take pride in, being not only the best Asian bad guy you can be, but the best of all bad guys. I wasnâ€™t willing to do anything to get in, but I think I developed the ability to take what I was given and do the best job I could,â€ he said.
	

	Born in Tokyo to an actress mother and Japanese American father who served in the military, Tagawa attended high school near Los Angeles, where he first started acting, and then attended USC. He began teaching his own style of martial arts called Chu Shin.

	He is survived by his children Calen, Byrnne and Cana, and two grandchildren, River and Thea Clayton.

schema.headline: Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa, Actor in â€˜Mortal Kombatâ€™ and â€˜The Man in the High Castle,â€™ Dies at 75

title: Hainan Jury Touts Festival as a Launchpad for Next Yearâ€™s Breakthrough Films
description: At the 7th Hainan Island International Film Festival in China, jury president Marco MÃ¼ller urged audiences and industry to rethink the eventâ€™s place
body:
At the 7th Hainan Island International Film Festival in China, jury president Marco MÃ¼ller urged audiences and industry to rethink the eventâ€™s place on the calendar, arguing that its slot between AFM and Berlin gives Hainan a unique chance to premiere the films that will define the coming year â€“ not recap the one thatâ€™s ending.

	Festival jurors acknowledged the challenges facing a young festival in an already overcrowded global film schedule. Speaking at a press conference introducing the festival jury, MÃ¼ller, jury president for HIIFFâ€™s Golden Coconut Award, attempted to redefine the festivalâ€™s schedule, late in the year, as its greatest strategic asset.
	

	Rather than presenting a summary of the current yearâ€™s films, MÃ¼ller argued that the HIIFF could be a platform that introduces groundbreaking films for the year ahead.


	â€œThe timing is particularly important,â€ MÃ¼ller stated, noting the festivalâ€™s placement, sandwiched between AFM in November, and the Berlin Film Festival in February. â€œThe Hainan Film Festivalâ€™s schedule happens to provide an opportunity to let young, media and film-obsessed audiences discover the newest films. That is, films that are coming out immediately next year.â€

	The sense of a festival still finding its footing between domestic focus and an international outlook was also evident in the responses of other jury members to questions ranging from Chinaâ€™s local box office to Asian-American representation in Hollywood.

	When asked about the latter, documentary juror and director Renee Tajima-PeÃ±a referenced the #OscarsSoWhite campaign and the push for greater AAPI representation in AMPAS.
	

	â€œWe really had to fight to gain a place at the table,â€ said Tajima-PeÃ±a. â€œWhen I first started out, Asian Americans were really marginalized in Hollywood, the entertainment business and documentaries.â€

	â€œMany of our stories are rooted here in China, and rooted in the Chinese diaspora story, and we are hungry to tell them.â€

	The press conference also threw up questions which gave insights into how Chinaâ€™s local media views the film industry at the moment. One question contended that the number of scripts entering production are decreasing, investment is becoming cautious, and distribution cycles are lengthening.

	In response, veteran Chinese actor Guo Tao suggested that the answer lay in balancing personal artistic expression with commercial sensibilities.

	â€œThe current film market needs more filmmakers to uphold the principle of â€˜content is king,â€™ focusing on the story. This is crucial,â€ said Guo. â€œWe have blockbuster films with high box office returns, while lacking artistic merit. The opposite is also true. We need to find a good balance between the two.â€

	The event also underscored the festivalâ€™s role in cultural diplomacy, with the 50th anniversary of China-Thailand diplomatic relations being celebrated with a series of Chinese-Thai events.

	â€œChina and Thailand have always been â€˜one family,'â€ said Thai director Banjong Pisanthanakun, referencing several Thai films that have resonated with Mainland Chinese audiences, like â€œHow To Make Millions Before Grandma Dies.â€

	While promotional posters for Hollywood juggernaut â€œAvatar: Fire and Ashâ€ line every walkway at the festival grounds, Argentine director Mariano LlinÃ¡s offered a gentle rebuff to the concept of the blockbuster film.

	LlinÃ¡s urged filmmakers to work on smaller films, and championed a return to intimate productions, a model he has long practiced as a founder of the El Pampero Cine film collective, which prioritizes small films and a revolving repertory cast of friends and family. He advocated for a filmmaking model driven by camaraderie rather than established film industry structures.

	â€œItâ€™s because itâ€™s been made and thought by a small group of people, not by a big enterprise or studio, and that would be the secret for a personal approach to cinema,â€ said LlinÃ¡s.
	

	â€œSo I think the idea of making a picture made by friends is the answer. Try to make your pictures small and smaller and they would belong to you in a deeper way.â€

schema.headline: Hainan Jury Touts Festival as a Launchpad for Next Yearâ€™s Breakthrough Films

title: How To Watch â€˜The Secret Lives of Mormon Wivesâ€™ Reunion Online
description:
If you purchase an independently reviewed product or service through a link on our website, Variety may receive an affiliate commission.

	From affa
body:
If you purchase an independently reviewed product or service through a link on our website, Variety may receive an affiliate commission.

	From affairs to betrayals to a whole lot of drama, itâ€™s been a tumultuous third season ofÂ  â€œThe Secret Lives of Mormon Wivesâ€ to say the least. If you, too, are wondering where things stand between the women of MomTok following the explosive finale, youâ€™re in luck: the Season 3 reunion will be available to stream exclusively on Hulu on Thursday, Dec. 4 starting at 9 p.m. PT.

	Stassi Schroeder of â€œVanderpump Rulesâ€ fame will host the event, which will reunite #MomTok and #DadTok â€œto explore the shocking scandals, uncover never-before-seen footage, and deck the halls with controversial guests,â€ per the official logline. Schroeder replaces Season 2 reunion host and â€œThe Bachelorâ€ alum Nick Viall.Â 


	Cast members Taylor Frankie Paul, Whitney Leavitt, Jen Affleck, Layla Taylor, Jessi Ngatikaura, Demi Engemann, Mikayla Matthews, Mayci Neeley and Miranda McWhoster, who joined the show in Season 2, will be in attendance. Wondering how to tune in? Hereâ€™s everything you need to know about streaming the special.Â 

	Since â€œMormon Wivesâ€ is currently exclusive to Hulu, you wonâ€™t be able to catch the reunion on cable. Instead, youâ€™ll need access to a Hulu account. A standalone subscription to the streaming service (with ads) starts at $11.99, while a Hulu Premium subscription, which grants viewers a commercial free experience, starts at $18.99. Users can also purchase Hulu as part of a bundle plan with Disney+, ESPN or HBO Max, starting at $12.99.Â  Once youâ€™re subscribed, youâ€™ll be able to stream the reunion on demand.

	Since premiering in 2024 following the groupâ€™s viral swinging scandal, â€œThe Secret Lives of Mormon Wivesâ€ has quickly become a fan favorite. While Season 3 data is yet to become available, the Season 2 premiere of the series hit five million views in its first five days of streaming on Hulu, according to Disney, while Season 1 was the streamerâ€™s most watched unscripted series premiere of 2024.


	Today, the women of MomTok are busier than ever. Affleck and Leavitt just competed on Season 34 of â€œDancing with the Stars,â€ while Paul is set to star as â€œThe Bachelorette,â€ premiering March 22, 2026. Additionally, Leavitt recently announced that sheâ€™ll be stepping into the role of Roxie Hart in â€œChicago,â€ making her Broadway debut in Feb. 2026.Â Â Â 

	The reunion is expected to have â€œmore drama than a high school Christmas pageant,â€ Schroeder said in the trailer. The eternal question remains: will MomTok survive this?

schema.headline: How To Watch â€˜The Secret Lives of Mormon Wivesâ€™ Reunion Online

title: â€˜The Batmanâ€™ Director Matt Reeves Stands Up for Paul Dano After Tarantinoâ€™s Diss: â€˜An Incredible Actorâ€™
description: Filmmaker Matt Reeves added his voice to the wave of praise for Paul Dano â€” an outpouring that was prompted by Quentin Tarantino dissing Dano as â€œth
body:
Filmmaker Matt Reeves added his voice to the wave of praise for Paul Dano â€” an outpouring that was prompted by Quentin Tarantino dissing Dano as â€œthe weakest fucking actor in SAG.â€

	â€œPaul Dano is an incredible actor, and an incredible person,â€ Reeves wrote on social media Thursday afternoon. The director worked with Dano on â€œThe Batman,â€ in which the actor took on the role of the villainous Riddler and faced off against Robert Pattinsonâ€™s Caped Crusader.
	

	Tarantino made his comments about Dano in an appearance on The Bret Easton Ellis Podcast, in which the filmmaker named his 20 favorite movies of the 21st century. But Tarantino upstaged his own taste a bit when discussing his fifth-place selection, Paul Thomas Andersonâ€™s â€œThere Will Be Blood,â€ arguing that the film would be his first or second pick â€œif it didnâ€™t have a big, giant flaw in itâ€¦ and the flaw is Paul Dano.â€


	â€œHe is weak sauce, man. He is the weak sister,â€ Tarantino continued. â€œHeâ€™s just such a weak, weak, uninteresting guy. Daniel Day-Lewis shows that he doesnâ€™t need a strong foil. The movie needs it. He doesnâ€™t need anything. Itâ€™s supposed to be a two-hander and itâ€™s not! â€¦ You put him with the the weakest fucking actor in SAG? The limpest dick in the world?â€

	The harsh take prompted others in the industry to voice their appreciation for Dano, including Reevesâ€™ â€œThe Batmanâ€ sequel screenwriter Mattson Tomlin: â€œI am really pleased to see so many people cheer on Paul Dano this week. Not only is he a terrific actor, but heâ€™s an astonishing director who exudes control and tremendous empathy. Check out â€˜Wildlifeâ€™ if you havenâ€™t seen it.â€
	

	Ben Stiller also showed his appreciation, writing on social media that â€œPaul Dano is f-ing brilliant.â€ Alec Baldwin shared a video statement saying, â€œI love Paul Dano. And if you donâ€™t love Paul Dano, shhhhhh.â€

schema.headline: â€˜The Batmanâ€™ Director Matt Reeves Stands Up for Paul Dano After Tarantinoâ€™s Diss: â€˜An Incredible Actorâ€™

title: Anonymous A-Listers Lobby Congress Against Netflix-WBD Acquisition: Streamer Would â€˜Hold a Noose Around the Theatrical Marketplaceâ€™ (EXCLUSIVE)
description: A consortium of top industry players have sent an open letter full of alarm to Congress, describing a potential economic and institutional meltdown
body:
A consortium of top industry players have sent an open letter full of alarm to Congress, describing a potential economic and institutional meltdown in Hollywood ifÂ Netflix succeeds in its effort to acquire Warner Bros. Discovery.

	The letter was sent via email to members of Congress from both parties on Thursday, from an anonymous collective identifying themselves only as â€œconcerned feature film producers.â€ The group explained it was leaving the letter unsigned â€œnot out of cowardiceâ€ but fear of retaliation, given Netflixâ€™s considerable power as a buyer and distributor. Netflix and Warner Bros. Discovery declined to comment.
	

	One well-placed source confirmed to Variety that the group includes a number of prominent filmmakers.


	The communication outlines three areas of great concern, including that Netflix could stand to â€œdestroyâ€ the theatrical film marketplace by escalating or eliminating the amount of time Warner Bros. films would play in theaters before hitting a combined Netflix-HBO Max streaming platform. Sources told Variety earlier on Thursday that Netflixâ€™s current proposal for Warner Bros. would have a theatrical window as thin as two weeks of exclusivity before moving to streaming. Another insider familiar with the deal process flatly denied this, saying the periods would be longer. Rival bidders Comcast and Paramount both have robust theatrical distribution outlets. Paramount has specifically pledged to keep Warner Bros. operating as a standalone business that will make a minimum of 14 films for theaters per year.

	The producers argued that Netflix would â€œeffectively hold a noose around the theatrical marketplace,â€ with what they assert would be enough market influence to reduce the footprint of theatrical movies and force down subsequent licensing fees paid in post-theatrical windows.
	

	The letter to Congress also references the many times Ted Sarandos, co-CEO of Netflix, has extolled that Netflixâ€™s business model has nothing to do with movie theaters (including a quote from a 2023 earnings call, where Sarandos said, â€œDriving folks to a theater is just not our businessâ€).

	The note concludes by urging members of the House and Senate to speak out publicly against the acquisition and afford the potential deal â€œthe highest level of antitrust scrutiny.â€ The stakes, the letter concludes, represent millions of jobs and a treasured art form.

schema.headline: Anonymous A-Listers Lobby Congress Against Netflix-WBD Acquisition: Streamer Would â€˜Hold a Noose Around the Theatrical Marketplaceâ€™ (EXCLUSIVE)

title: Blackpinkâ€™s Lisa, Don Lee and â€˜Squid Gameâ€™ Star Lee Jin-uk to Lead Netflixâ€™s â€˜Extractionâ€™ Universe Thriller â€˜Tygoâ€™
description: Netflix has unveiled â€œTygo,â€ an action thriller that will see Blackpink member Lalisa â€œLisaâ€ Manobalâ€™s star alongside Korean action powerhouse Don L
body:
Netflix has unveiled â€œTygo,â€ an action thriller that will see Blackpink member Lalisa â€œLisaâ€ Manobalâ€™s star alongside Korean action powerhouse Don Lee and â€œSquid Gameâ€ actor Lee Jin-uk.

	The project is an expansion of Netflixâ€™s â€œExtractionâ€ franchise, bringing Korean filmmaking prowess to the streamerâ€™s most successful action property. Big Punch Pictures, AGBO and TGIM are producing, with Nova Film Inc and B&C Group serving as co-producers.
	

	The film is based on an original graphic novel created by Anthony and Joe Russo with Ande Parks. The producing team includes Don Lee for Big Punch Pictures; Anthony and Joe Russo, Angela Russo-Otstot, Michael Disco, and Albert J. Kim for AGBO; Won-ki Choi for Nova Film; and Chris S. Lee for B&C Group.


	â€œTygoâ€ follows Tygo (Don Lee), a former child soldier turned mercenary who launches a revenge mission through Koreaâ€™s criminal underworld after an operation goes awry. The film will be written by Cha Woo-jin and directed by Lee Sang-yong, who previously helmed â€œThe Roundupâ€ and â€œThe Roundup: No Way Out.â€

	Lisa, who starred in â€œThe White Lotusâ€ Season 3, said: â€œIâ€™m so honored to be a part of this project and grateful for the opportunity to work alongside such incredible actors. Being in an action movie has always been a dream of mine, so for my film debut to be such an exciting project feels very special.â€

	Don Leeâ€™s credits include â€œThe Roundupâ€ franchise and Marvelâ€™s â€œEternals.â€ â€œIâ€™m thrilled that this project, which Iâ€™ve been developing for years with AGBO, is finally moving into production,â€ Lee said. â€œâ€™Tygoâ€™ brings a distinctly Korean identity into the global â€˜Extractionâ€™ universe. We canâ€™t wait to unleash its explosive energy on audiences worldwide.â€
	

	Lee Jin-uk added: â€œAs a fan of the â€˜Extractionâ€™ franchise, itâ€™s a great honor for me to join this universe. Iâ€™m especially excited and grateful to be working with Don, whom Iâ€™ve always admired, and with Lisa as well.â€

	Angela Russo-Otstot, producer and chief creative officer of AGBO, said: â€œWeâ€™re thrilled to explore the world of â€˜Extractionâ€™ through a South Korean lens, teaming up with legendary action star Don Lee and visionary director Lee Sang-yong, whose dynamic choreography exemplifies the world-class craft of Korean cinema. Together, we proudly welcome Lisa, a truly multitalented global phenomenon, and Lee Jin-uk, one of Koreaâ€™s most charismatic and versatile actors, to lead our cast alongside Don.â€

	The â€œExtractionâ€ franchise has proven remarkably successful for Netflix, with 90 million households watching the first film within its initial four weeks. The second installment remained at No. 1 on Netflixâ€™s Global Top 10 Movies list for seven weeks, accumulating over 123 million views.

schema.headline: Blackpinkâ€™s Lisa, Don Lee and â€˜Squid Gameâ€™ Star Lee Jin-uk to Lead Netflixâ€™s â€˜Extractionâ€™ Universe Thriller â€˜Tygoâ€™

title: â€˜Train Dreamsâ€™ Cinematographer Adolpho Veloso Shot the Film Using 99% of Natural Light
description:
Clint Bentleyâ€™s â€œTrain Dreamsâ€ follows the Joel Edgerton as Robert Grainier, a logger and railroad worker living in the Pacific NorthWest.

	Set in
body:
Clint Bentleyâ€™s â€œTrain Dreamsâ€ follows the Joel Edgerton as Robert Grainier, a logger and railroad worker living in the Pacific NorthWest.

	Set in the late 1960s, â€œTrain Dreamsâ€ is directed by â€œSing Singâ€ co-writer Clint Bentley who called on Adolpho Veloso to be the filmâ€™s cinematographer.

	The images are lush. The tall green trees pop against the clear blue sky, until a wildfire ravages the forest and changes Graingerâ€™s life. Suddenly, the palette is ash and grey reflecting the aftermath.
	

	Velosoâ€™s imagery is one that lingers long after the film credits have rolled. In one scene, itâ€™s a grand moment, as the tall trees get sawed down all in the name of progress.

	Veloso sat down with Variety for Inside the Frame and said, â€œFor 99% of the movie, we used natural light.â€

	With Bentley shooting in real-life locations, the idea was to simulate the audience looking through memories and putting a life together where those the images were being shown. In this case, those memories belong to Edgertonâ€™s character, Robert.

	For research, Veloso looked through a lot of old pictures from the era and even as far back as 1920. As he was going through them, it dawned on him that they looked like the 3:20 aspect ratio. Says Veloso, â€œWe just kept going back to this memory feeling. We were like, â€˜Why we just donâ€™t use that aspect ratio?â€™â€

	Once they had that, Veloso knew this would be an intimate film, and also tried to capture the beauty of the natural setting. To properly film in natural light and capture the beauty of the landscape, Veloso says, â€œWe knew we needed a smaller camera and because of the natural lightâ€¦we just decided to go with the Alexa 35 to have a lot of dynamic range.â€
	

	Similarly, for the scenes at night, natural was key, so he used real fire and candles to light those. He says, â€œWe wanted to keep it that way to feel a bit more grounded.â€

	The lush imagery in the film was captured using Kowa Spherical lenses. At night, he switched to Zeiss Super Speeds lenses.

	After the forest fire devastates much of the landscape, and Graingerâ€™s home, the earthy tones disappear with very little pops of green. That was all natural, Veloso says.

	Watch the video above.

schema.headline: â€˜Train Dreamsâ€™ Cinematographer Adolpho Veloso Shot the Film Using 99% of Natural Light

title: Chicagoâ€™s Music Box Theatre to Add Third Screen and Acquire Heights Theater in Minneapolis â€“ Film News in Brief
description: Chicagoâ€™s Music Box Theatre has plans to add a new 100-seat third screen at its Southport Avenue location and acquire the Heights Theater in Minneap
body:
Chicagoâ€™s Music Box Theatre has plans to add a new 100-seat third screen at its Southport Avenue location and acquire the Heights Theater in Minneapolis, Minn., in 2026.

	The Music Boxâ€™s longtime owner-operators, Brody Sheldon and the Schopf Family, will partner with Ryan Oestreich to oversee the transition of the theatre.

	Under the new ownership, Heights Theater will close for a short period of time after its annual New Yearâ€™s Day screening of â€œHoliday Inn.â€ It will reopen on Jan. 9, 2026, with Jim Jarmuschâ€™s â€œFather Mother Sister Brother,â€ additional classic repertory titles and new programming curated by the Music Box team.
	

	The traditions that will remain at Heights Theater include â€œWhite Christmasâ€ screenings, â€œHoliday Innâ€ on New Yearâ€™s Day, the Celebration of Cinema festival and partnerships with Trylon Cinema.


	New additions will feature late-night screenings on Friday and Saturday night, kidsâ€™ Saturday morning cinema and a revitalized silent cinema series with a live organ accompaniment.

	Music Box Theatreâ€™s third screen expansion will debut in summer 2026. The project is funded by ownership and supported by a community development grant from the city of Chicago.

	The new venue will allow for expanded independent, international and repertory programming alongside increased opportunities for filmmaker events, festivals and extended runs. Additional community partnerships and special presentations will also be included.
	
		Thursday, December 4	

	Doc Societyâ€™s Climate Story Unit Announces Story Fund Grants
	

	Doc Societyâ€™s Climate Story Unit announced the 2025 Climate Story Fund grantees â€“ selecting seven visionary new projects from an unprecedented global pool of applicants. This year, the Fund received808 applications from 122 countries, submitted in English, Spanish, Portuguese, and French, reflecting the rapidly growing international demand for ambitious, justice-centered climate storytelling.

	The Climate Story Unit has awarded seven new grants totaling $765,000 USD, supporting both creative production and strategic impact initiatives.

	Since its launch in 2019, the Climate Story Unit has awarded $6.3 million directly to storytellers, impact producers, and cultural allies, supporting 59 climate-themed stories across all mediums. The Fund provides grants of up to $125,000 to support both production and impact campaigns. In 2025 alone, the Fund continues to deepen this commitment with targeted investments designed to scale the ambitionand reach of global climate storytelling.

	Gravillis Inc. Names KaLynn Jenkins as Chief Operating Officer 

	KaLynn Jenkins has joined Gravillis Inc. as the creative agencyâ€™s new Chief Operating Officer (COO). Most recently, Jenkins served as Vice President of Operations at Skydance Media.Â 

	In her new role, Jenkins will oversee a range of operations while driving strategic growth initiatives, working closely with CEO Kenny Gravillis to scale the agency, expand revenue streams and strengthen client partnerships.Â Â 

	â€œAs our agency moves forward and expands, KaLynn is the perfect complement to embody that growth,â€ said Gravillis in a statement. â€œHer experience and energy is a valuable asset for the future of the company, as well as keeping our operations efficient and flexible for this ever-changing landscape called â€˜entertainment.â€™â€

	Currently celebrating its 25th anniversary, Gravillis is the agency behind some of the most memorable recent campaigns including Sinners, Spike Leeâ€™s â€œHighest 2 Lowestâ€ starring Denzel Washington, â€œCaptain America: Brave New World,â€ Viola Davisâ€™ â€œG20,â€ the Motion Picture Academy and the upcoming â€œBack to the Futureâ€ 40th Anniversary release.
	
		Tuesday, December 2	

	BAFTA Unveils 2025 Breakthrough US Cohort Recipients

	The 2025 BAFTA Breakthrough US cohort has been unveiled, featuring 12 creatives working across film, television and games in the United States. Apple TV will be this yearâ€™s sponsor.Â 
	

	Read the full list of this yearâ€™s BAFTA Breakthrough US cohort.Â 

	US Breakthroughs:

	Brandon Wilson, actor â€“Â  â€œNickel Boysâ€ (Film)Â 

	Brittany Shyne, director â€“ â€œSeedsâ€ (Film, Documentary)Â 

	Chase Infiniti, actor â€“ â€œPresumed Innocentâ€ (Television)Â 

	Erika Ishii, voice performer â€“ â€œGhost of Yoteiâ€ (Games)Â 

	Eva Victor, writer, director, actor â€“ â€œSorry, Babyâ€ (Film)Â 

	Frida Perez, writer, producer â€“ â€œThe Studioâ€ (Television)Â 

	Karla Reyes, creative director â€“ â€œTake Us Northâ€ (Games)Â 

	Mia Cioffi Henry, cinematographer â€“ â€œSorry, Babyâ€ (Film)Â 

	Miles Caton, actor â€“ â€œSinnersâ€ (Film)Â 

	Min Ji (Maggie) Kang, writer, director â€“ â€œKPop Demon Huntersâ€ (Film)Â 

	Paige Bethmann, director â€“ â€œRemaining Nativeâ€ (Film, Documentary)Â 

	Xalavier Nelson Jr., studio headÂ  â€“Â  â€œI Am Your Beastâ€ (Games)Â 

	The BAFTA Breakthrough US cohort was selected by a jury lead by Channing Godfrey Peoples, Davina Pardo, Jessica Hernandez, Kate Edwards, Nyasha Hatendi, Paul Rogers, Sam Enoch, Simone Ling for film & television and Andrew Prahlow, Arjun Yadav, Carmen Askerneese, Del Walker, Dmitri Johnson, Julia Bianco Schoeffling, Tara Voelker for games.Â 

	Art Directors Guild to Honor Four Visionaries with Lifetime Achievement Awards

	The Art Directors Guild will honor four of its members with Lifetime Achievement Awards at the 30th Annual Excellence in Production Design Awards on Feb. 28, 2026.

	The Awards will be presented to Production Designer Bo Welch, art decorator and set designer Jann Engel, storyboard artist and production designer Tom Southwell and scenic artist Stephen McNallyÂ for their exceptional careers in their respective fields.

	Welch is an Oscar-nominated production designer responsible for creating the distinctive looks of â€œBeetlejuice,â€ â€œBatman Returns,â€ â€œEdward Scissorhands,â€ â€œMen in Black,â€ â€œThe Birdcageâ€ and the Netflix series â€œA Series of Unfortunate Events.â€ Meanwhile, Jann Engel is a two-time ADG Awards winner whose credits as an art director and set designer include â€œMemoirs of a Geisha,â€ â€œMars Attacks!,â€ â€œLegends of the Fall,â€ â€œRoad to Perdition,â€ â€œAddams Family Valuesâ€ and several Marvel films including â€œThe Avengers,â€ â€œAvengers: Infinity War,â€ â€œAvengers: Endgameâ€ and â€œGuardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2.â€
	

	Southwellâ€™s storyboard and production design talents have created the aesthetics for â€œBlade Runner,â€ â€œX-Men,â€ â€œDisturbia,â€ â€œNavy Seals,â€ â€œArachnophobiaâ€ and his fruitful collaborations with director Ron Underwood on â€œCity Slickers,â€ â€œHeart and Souls,â€ â€œSpeechlessâ€ and â€œMighty Joe Young.â€ Finally, McNallyÂ has provided the scenic direction for â€œAnna and the King,â€ â€œVenom: Let There Be Carnage,â€ â€œWhat Dreams May Come,â€ â€œFlubberâ€ and the TV show â€œTrauma.â€ He also builds and paints scenery for the San Francisco Opera.

	The 30th Annual Excellence in Production Design Awards will be held at the InterContinental in Downtown Los Angeles. The ceremony will be produced byÂ Megan Elizabeth Bell,Â Michael Allen Glover andÂ Tom Wilkins.Â 
	
		Monday, December 1	

	Joseph Kosinski and Jerry Bruckheimer to Receive Harold Lloyd Honor at Lumiere AwardsÂ 

	â€œF1â€ director Joseph Kosinski and producer Jerry Bruckheimer will receive the Harold Lloyd Award at the 16th annual Lumiere Awards luncheon on Feb. 9, 2026, at the Beverly Hills Hotel.

	The award celebrates their outstanding achievement in cinematic storytelling and technological innovation, most recently exemplified by their acclaimed collaboration on Apple Original Filmsâ€™ â€œF1.â€

	Following its theatrical release on June 27, â€œF1â€ debuted as the No. 1 film at the global box office and has since grossed over $630 million worldwide, making it the highest-grossing original feature of the year.

	Other collaborations from the duo include â€œTop Gun: Maverick.â€ Kosinskiâ€™s directing credits featureÂ  â€œOblivion,â€ â€œTron: Legacyâ€ and â€œOnly The Brave.â€ Bruckheimer is known for â€œPirates of the Caribbean,â€ â€œTop Gun,â€ â€œNational Treasure,â€ â€œBad Boysâ€ and â€œBeverly Hills Copâ€ franchises.Â

title: Donâ€™t Forget About â€˜The Life of Chuckâ€™ This Oscar Season, the Feel-Good Apocalypse Movie of the Year
description: Who knew the end of the world could be so life-affirming? And who would have guessed that a Stephen King short story adapted by fellow Master of Hor
body:
Who knew the end of the world could be so life-affirming? And who would have guessed that a Stephen King short story adapted by fellow Master of Horror Mike Flanagan would result in the feel-good movie of the year?

	The challenge with talking about â€œThe Life of Chuckâ€ is that itâ€™s a film that should be discovered â€” the less you know going in, the better. Which made it challenging to market. Is it a drama? A musical? A romance? A coming-of-age story? A movie that does nothing less than ask about the meaning of life? Well, yes.
	

	The film is broken into three acts, told in reverse chronology. The first act finds the world crumbling due to an unspecified apocalyptic event. The internet is down, thereâ€™s no television â€” and yet mysterious billboards and commercials thanking someone named Charles â€œChuckâ€ Krantz begin popping up everywhere. In the second act, we meet a grown Chuck (played by Tom Hiddleston) on a pivotal day in his life. The third act details Chuckâ€™s childhood, where heâ€™s raised by his grandfather Albie (Mark Hamill, never better). All questions about Chuck will be answered as the story examines big questions about the universe through the life of one ordinary man.Â 


	Itâ€™s an act of courage to be earnest and optimistic in a world where audiences arenâ€™t accustomed to sincerity. â€œWe live in a cynical world and we work in a cynical industry,â€ says Flanagan. â€œWeâ€™re kind of instructed to be cynical, to be on guard and not to lead with our emotions, because thatâ€™s vulnerable.â€ To that end, Flanagan and company knew their film wouldnâ€™t appeal to everyone.Â 
	

	But people have responded â€” the film was the winner of the coveted Audience Award at last yearâ€™s Toronto International Film Festival. Hamillâ€™s wife is also a fan. â€œShe never hesitates to say: â€˜This is my favorite thing heâ€™s ever done,â€™â€ the actor reveals. And perhaps the greatest endorsement came from King himself, who the filmmaker says told him: â€œI donâ€™t know how it will play for everyone, but this works for me because its heart is on its sleeve.â€

	Huge credit is due to the outstanding ensemble â€” in addition to Hamill and Hiddleston, Flanagan regulars like Jacob Tremblay, Kate Siegel and Annalise Basso make appearances, proving the old adage that thereâ€™s no such thing as a small role. Karen Gillan (also a return player) and Chiwetel Ejiofor play a divorced couple in one of the most romantic scenes of the year. And Nick Offerman gives one of the best performances of the year simply by lending his voice to the Narrator. But itâ€™s Benjamin Pajak as 11-year-old Chuck and Hamill who provide the heart and soul of the film. Flanagan is known for his gorgeous dialogue, and it may sound like a joke, but Hamill articulates a monologue to Pajak about the importance of math that sounds like poetry.

	Itâ€™s a stunning achievement, especially considering King himself never thought it would happen. Asked why Flanagan is such a good interpreter of his work, he declared the director to be fearless. â€œI never would have believed, out of all the stories Iâ€™ve ever written, that â€˜The Life of Chuckâ€™ would ever be a movie,â€ King notes. How happy he was to be proven wrong.

schema.headline: Donâ€™t Forget About â€˜The Life of Chuckâ€™ This Oscar Season, the Feel-Good Apocalypse Movie of the Year

title: Billy Porter Joins Documentary Short â€˜Freeman Vinesâ€™ as Executive Producer (EXCLUSIVE)
description:
Billy Porter has joined the Oscar-qualified documentary short, â€œFreeman Vines,â€ as an executive producer.

	Directors AndrÃ© Robert Lee and Tim Kirkm
body:
Billy Porter has joined the Oscar-qualified documentary short, â€œFreeman Vines,â€ as an executive producer.

	Directors AndrÃ© Robert Lee and Tim Kirkmanâ€™s film is a haunting portrait of 82-year-old Freeman Vines, a sculptor and guitar-maker in rural Fountain, N.C., who carves some of his instruments from lumber taken from a tree used in the lynching of a young Black man named Oliver Moore. As Vines faces multiple myeloma and diabetes late in life, the film captures his philosophy, humor and unflinching confrontation with the legacy of racism in the American South.Â 
	

	â€œFreeman Vines was a fierce, extraordinary human, and this expression of his story is simply gorgeous,â€ Porter said in a statement Thursday. â€œThe life of an artist can be a hard road, and Freeman navigated a complicated community and history, but he discovered what it meant to live in truth with a freedom he claimed for himself. We should all be so lucky. â€˜Freeman Vines,â€™ directed by AndrÃ© Robert Lee and Tim Kirkman, offers a profound lesson about human connection, resilience and creativity. I am honored to be part of this project, and I hope audiences will truly witness it.â€


	The film took home top honors at multiple Academy-qualifying festivals, including best documentary short at the Tallahassee Film Festival and screened at Tribeca, RiverRun and Florida Film Festivals, as well as selections at Woodstock, Nantucket, Indy Shorts, SCAD Savannah, and other leading showcases.

	Earlier this fall, the film was acquired by Switchboard Magazine and is currently available to screen via their YouTube Channel. 
	

	In addition to Porterâ€™s company Incognegro, producer Gill Hollandâ€™s company The Group Entertainment presents the film in association with Leeâ€™s Many Things Productions, Kirkmanâ€™s T42 Entertainment and Music Maker Foundation.

	â€œBilly Porter is an American icon in the arts, and it is an honor to partner with him on â€˜Freeman Vines,'â€ Lee and Kirkman said. â€œWe are excited to have Billyâ€™s extraordinary talent and voice on this journey to help bring Freemanâ€™s life story and lifeâ€™s work to an even greater audience.â€ 

	Switchboard founder and editor in chief Celia Aniskovich said, â€œâ€™Freeman Vinesâ€™ story sits at the intersection of music, art, race and spiritual inquiry â€” the exact kind of layered, character-driven storytelling Switchboard was built to support. As we bring together four Oscar-qualified shorts for a collective awards campaign, â€˜Freeman Vinesâ€™ is a soul-stirring cornerstone of that slate. Weâ€™re thrilled to welcome Billy Porter to the team as we introduce this film to wider audiences.â€

	â€œFreeman Vinesâ€ is one of four Oscar-qualified shorts â€” alongside â€œPoreless,â€ â€œRat Rodâ€ and â€œSaving Supermanâ€ â€” being championed in Switchboardâ€™s collective awards campaign this season.Â Â

schema.headline: Billy Porter Joins Documentary Short â€˜Freeman Vinesâ€™ as Executive Producer (EXCLUSIVE)

title: 'Mortal Kombat' Star Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa Dead at 75
body:
'Mortal Kombat'
                          Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa Dead at 75
                      
                  
                        Published December 4, 2025 5:54 PM PST
                                                                            
      
    
          Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa, an actor famous for his work in the 'Mortal Kombat' franchise, is dead.
      
    
          Tagawa died Thursday in Santa Barbara, California, the result of complications from a stroke ... his family tells Deadline.
      
    
          He was reportedly surrounded by family, including his children, when he died.
      
    
          Tagawa is famous for playing Shang Tsung, an evil sorcerer, in 'Mortal Kombat' movies, TV shows, and video games.
      
    
          In addition to his work in 'Mortal Kombat,' Tagawa is also known for his roles in "The Last Emperor", "Memoirs of a Geisha" and "The Man in the High Castle."
      
    
          Tagawa was a martial artist trained in Kendo. He was born in Japan but moved to Fort Bragg, North Carolina when he was 5 years old. In a 2010 interview, he recalled being Japanese in the South in the 1950s ... saying it was "pretty tough."
      
    
          Among his nearly 150 acting credits ... "Big Trouble in Little China," "Tekken," "Pearl Harbor," "Planet of the Apes," "Elektra," "Snow Falling on Cedars," "47 Ronin" and "License to Kill."
      
    
          Tagawa was 75.
      
    
          RIP
      
      
              
            
              Related articles
            
        
              
          
                          
                Celebrity News

schema.headline: 'Mortal Kombat' Star Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa Dead at 75

title: NBA Champion Elden Campbell's Cause of Death Revealed
description:
Elden Campbell
                          Cause Of Death Revealed
                          ... Ac
body:
Elden Campbell
                          Cause Of Death Revealed
                          ... Accidental Drowning
                      
                  
                        Published December 4, 2025 12:49 PM PST
                                                                      |
                Updated December 4, 2025 3:08 PM PST
                                    
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          NBA champion Elden Campbell's cause of death has been revealed ... with officials telling TMZ Sports the former Laker died due to an accidental drowning.
      
    
          The medical examiner in Florida says Campbell -- who was 57 years old -- was pronounced deceased at 8:03 PM on December 1.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          The news of his tragic death was first announced by his former teammates and professional and college organizations.
      

          The 6'11" center spent 15 years in the NBA -- more than half of that run with the Los Angeles Lakers, who drafted Campbell in the first round in 1990.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          He also suited up for the Charlotte/New Orleans Hornets, Seattle SuperSonics, Detroit Pistons, New Jersey Nets and Detroit Pistons ... winning a championship with Motor City in 2004.
      
    
          Campbell's family released a statement on the loss ... saying, "Elden was a man of faith who trusted in his lord and savior Jesus Christ. Â Husband, father, brother, cousin and friend."
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          "He was a man to whom family meant everything -- generous, funny, disciplined and kind, but could shut you down if required. A man of God, he passed doing what he loved; fishing out on the ocean, enjoying his idea of an ideal day."
      
    
          Campbell is survived by his wife, four children and three siblings.

title: Tim Walz Says People Drive by His House Calling Him R-Word After Trump Slur
description:
Tim Walz
                          Drive-By Attacks On My Home ...
                          Peop
body:
Tim Walz
                          Drive-By Attacks On My Home ...
                          People Are Shouting R-Word, Trump!!!
                      
                  
                        Published December 4, 2025 1:06 PM PST
                                                                            
      
    
        
                    
                  
      
    
          Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz says his home is being hit by a non-stop barrage of drive-bys ... but instead of bullets ... nasty words are shooting out of the cars -- namely, the R-word.
      
    
          Walz says people keep driving by his house shouting the R-word at him ... and he's noticed it happening more and more since President Trump called him that specific slur in a recent social media post.
      
    
        
                    
                  
      
    
          Trump was given a chance to walk back the statement last week, but he doubled down and told reporters, "I think there is something wrong with him."
      

          Walz says not one Republican lawmaker has condemned the R-word being directed at him ... calling it "shameful."
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          The failed vice presidential candidate says alarm bells should be going off here ... he says rhetoric like this can turn into violence ... and we've already seen politicians in his state targeted by a gunman.
      
    
          Walz had clapped back at Trump with a simple, deadly one-liner after the social media post ... but he's striking a different tone here.
      
      
              
            
              Related articles
            
        
              
          
                          
                Tim Walz
              
                          
                Politix
              
                          
                News
              
                          
                Fights & Feuds

schema.headline: Tim Walz Says People Drive by His House Calling Him R-Word After Trump Slur
